items.name: ANTIFREEZE
items.description: Check with your local auto parts store, most accept old antifreeze, and some communities have recycling programs for antifreeze you can also take the antifreeze to a household hazardous waste facility.

items.name: FILE FOLDERS
items.description: Once you separate the metal hangers from the paper, both components can be recycled.

items.name: GAMING CONSOLES
items.description: Visit the e-Stewards website to find a recycler.

items.name: GLASS
items.description: Bottle glass is one of the easiest items to recycle; simply place in your curbside collections bin.

items.name: BOOKS
items.description: These can be recycled in the paper bin, an alternative you can donate them to Booksforsoldiers.com or www.recycleyourtextbooks.com.

items.name: CELL PHONES
items.description: Many cellphone companies offer trade-ins, or you can donate your no-longer-used phone.

items.name: JAM JARS
items.description: Jam jars, sans their metal lids, can be rinsed and recycled with bottle glass.

items.name: METAL
items.description: Metals like aluminum cans can often be recycled through curbside collection programs. Other metals may need to be taken to a drop-off center for recycling or proper disposal.

items.name: MAGAZINES
items.description: Since magazines are made of paper, they are 100 percent recyclable and are accepted by most recycling centers and pickup programs.

items.name: POST-ITS
items.description: Post-its can be recycled with paper. You don’t need to worry about the sticky side, it gets sorted out during the recycling process.

items.name: PIZZA BOXES
items.description: Rip out any areas soiled by food residue like cheese or grease and recycle the rest as corrugated cardboard.

items.name: SOAP DISPENSERS
items.description: Many bathroom bottles, including soap dispensers, are marked with resin code 2 or 4, which makes them easily recyclable.

items.name: WATER BOTTLES
items.description: Check with your city’s curbside or drop off recycling program to see which plastics they accept.

items.name: ZIPPERS
items.description: Donate your used zippers to a craft group. Places that recycle metal may be willing to take zippers if you cut off the fabric before you drop them off.

items.name: BACKPACKS
items.description: Contact youth programs in your area; backpacks might be useful for outings or trips. You could also donate them to a local church.

items.name: CANDLES
items.description: Make a new candle by reusing the wax from your old candle scraps.

items.name: FIRE EXTINGUISHERS
items.description: Contact your local fire department to find out if your empty extinguisher can be refilled or exchanged for one that is ready for use.

items.name: HANGERS – PLASTIC
items.description: These are best donated; thrift stores are usually happy to receive extra hangers.

items.name: KEYS
items.description: Keys can be recycled at most local recycling centers or sold as scrap metal.

items.name: LOTION BOTTLES
items.description: Check the plastic number to be sure, but most bottles can easily be recycled in your curbside pickup bin.

items.name: QUARTZ
items.description: While glass quartz is not the same as other glass products, it is recyclable. Contact your local recycling center to see if they accept glass quartz.

items.name: TIN CANS
items.description: If you have a curbside recycling program, tin and steel cans are usually accepted.

items.name: HANGERS – WIRE
items.description: These can be recycled as scrap metal, or returned to your dry cleaner. Hanger manufacturers can reform even bent hangers.

items.name: KITCHEN UTENSILS
items.description: Since kitchen utensils are commonly made of steel, an iron-chromium alloy, they can be recycled as scrap metal.

items.name: PLASTIC BAGS
items.description: Plastic shopping bags can be returned to many grocery stores for recycling.
